title: Checkpoint: Minimum Payment Disaster + Loan Comparison
description: Assessment covering Unit 4 credit and debt skills. Students analyze the true cost of credit card minimum payments, compare loan options by total cost, interpret amortization table snippets, and identify predatory lending red flags. This is the most consequential checkpoint in the course.

remediationStrategy.description: Credit and debt literacy is arguably the most impactful skill set in this course. Students below threshold MUST demonstrate understanding before moving forward.

clusters.reteachFocus: Monthly interest = APR÷12 × balance, minimum payment trap (mostly interest, barely touches principal), payoff comparison at different payment levels
Total cost = monthly payment × number of payments, comparing loans by total cost not monthly payment, shorter term = more monthly but less total
Early payments mostly interest / late payments mostly principal, why extra early payments save the most, reading an amortization table snippet
Payday loan APR calculation (400%+), red flags checklist, comparing predatory vs legitimate loan options

assessmentProblems.question: Your credit card has a balance of $3,800 and an APR (annual percentage rate) of 19.99%. Credit card interest is calculated monthly. What is the interest charge for one month? Round to the nearest cent.
assessmentProblems.answer: The monthly interest rate is the APR divided by 12: 19.99% ÷ 12 = 1.666%. As a decimal: 0.1999 ÷ 12 = 0.016658. Monthly interest charge = $3,800 × 0.016658 = $63.30. This means $63.30 is added to the balance every month just for carrying the debt — before any fees, purchases, or payments.

assessmentProblems.question:
You owe $2,400 on a credit card with a 21.99% APR. Your minimum payment is 2% of the balance.
(a) How much is this month's minimum payment?
(b) How much of that minimum payment goes toward interest?
(c) How much actually reduces your balance (goes toward principal)?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) Minimum payment = $2,400 × 0.02 = $48.00. (b) Monthly interest rate = 21.99% ÷ 12 = 1.8325%. Interest charge = $2,400 × 0.018325 = $43.98. (c) Principal paid = $48.00 − $43.98 = $4.02. Only $4.02 of the $48 payment actually reduces the balance — that's just 8.4% of the payment. The other 91.6% goes straight to the credit card company as interest. At this rate, it would take decades to pay off the card.

assessmentProblems.question:
Marcus owes $5,000 on a credit card with 22.99% APR. He is considering two payoff strategies:

• Strategy A: Pay $100/month → estimated payoff: 167 months (nearly 14 years), total paid: $16,601
• Strategy B: Pay $250/month → estimated payoff: 25 months (about 2 years), total paid: $6,194

(a) How much total interest does each strategy cost?
(b) How much interest does Marcus save by choosing Strategy B?
(c) In your own words, explain why the difference is so dramatic.
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) Strategy A total interest = $16,601 − $5,000 = $11,601. Strategy B total interest = $6,194 − $5,000 = $1,194. (b) Interest saved = $11,601 − $1,194 = $10,407. By paying $150 more per month, Marcus saves $10,407 in interest and pays off the debt 142 months (nearly 12 years) sooner. (c) At $100/month, almost the entire payment goes to interest each month (the first month's interest alone is $95.79 of the $100 payment). The balance barely shrinks, so interest keeps piling up month after month for over a decade. At $250/month, a much larger chunk attacks the principal each month, so the balance drops quickly and generates less interest. This is the minimum payment trap — the credit card company profits enormously from customers who pay only the minimum.

assessmentProblems.question: You are buying a used car for $18,000 and take out a loan at 5.9% APR for 48 months with a monthly payment of $423.35. What is the total amount you will pay over the life of the loan? How much of that is interest?
assessmentProblems.answer: Total paid = $423.35 × 48 = $20,320.80. Total interest = $20,320.80 − $18,000.00 = $2,320.80. You pay $2,320.80 in interest over 4 years for the privilege of borrowing $18,000.

assessmentProblems.question:
You want to buy a $22,000 car and have two loan offers:

• Loan A: 4.9% APR for 48 months, monthly payment of $506.69
• Loan B: 6.9% APR for 72 months, monthly payment of $373.15

Loan B has a lower monthly payment. Calculate the total cost and total interest for each loan. Which loan actually costs less overall?
assessmentProblems.answer: Loan A: Total cost = $506.69 × 48 = $24,321.12. Total interest = $24,321.12 − $22,000 = $2,321.12. Loan B: Total cost = $373.15 × 72 = $26,866.80. Total interest = $26,866.80 − $22,000 = $4,866.80. Loan A costs $2,545.68 less overall ($26,866.80 − $24,321.12), even though its monthly payment is $133.54 higher. The shorter term and lower rate save significant interest. A lower monthly payment does NOT mean a better deal — always compare total cost.

assessmentProblems.question:
Priya can afford $400/month for a car payment. She is considering three options:

• Loan A: $20,000 car at 5.5% APR for 48 months → $465.34/month (over budget)
• Loan B: $20,000 car at 7.2% APR for 60 months → $397.88/month
• Loan C: $17,000 car at 5.5% APR for 48 months → $395.54/month

Loan A exceeds her budget. Between Loans B and C, calculate the total cost of each. Which should she choose, and why?
assessmentProblems.answer: Loan B: Total = $397.88 × 60 = $23,872.80. Interest = $23,872.80 − $20,000 = $3,872.80. Loan C: Total = $395.54 × 48 = $18,985.92. Interest = $18,985.92 − $17,000 = $1,985.92. Priya should choose Loan C. It saves $1,886.88 in interest ($3,872.80 − $1,985.92), is paid off a full year sooner, and actually has a slightly lower monthly payment ($395.54 vs $397.88). The trade-off is a slightly less expensive car ($17,000 vs $20,000), but she builds equity faster and frees up her budget sooner. Stretching for more car with a longer, higher-rate loan is a common and costly mistake.

assessmentProblems.question:
Below is a snippet from an amortization table for a $20,000 auto loan at 6.0% APR for 60 months (monthly payment: $386.66):

| Payment # | Payment  | Interest | Principal | Remaining Balance |
|-----------|----------|----------|-----------|-------------------|
| 1         | $386.66  | $100.00  | $286.66   | $19,713.34        |
| 2         | $386.66  | $98.57   | $288.09   | $19,425.25        |
| 3         | $386.66  | $97.13   | $289.53   | $19,135.72        |

(a) What percentage of Payment #1 goes to interest?
(b) Why does the interest portion decrease with each payment?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) $100.00 ÷ $386.66 = 0.2586 = 25.9%. More than a quarter of the first payment is pure interest. (b) Each month, the remaining balance decreases (from $20,000 to $19,713.34 to $19,425.25, etc.). Since monthly interest is calculated as (APR ÷ 12) × remaining balance, a lower balance means less interest. As the interest portion shrinks, more of the fixed $386.66 payment goes toward principal, which further reduces the balance — creating a virtuous cycle that accelerates payoff over time.

assessmentProblems.question:
Here is a snippet from near the END of the same $20,000 loan (6.0% APR, 60 months, $386.66/month):

| Payment # | Payment  | Interest | Principal | Remaining Balance |
|-----------|----------|----------|-----------|-------------------|
| 57        | $386.66  | $7.61    | $379.05   | $1,143.83         |
| 58        | $386.66  | $5.72    | $380.94   | $762.89           |
| 59        | $386.66  | $3.81    | $382.85   | $380.04           |

Compare Payment #1 (interest: $100.00, principal: $286.66) to Payment #58 (interest: $5.72, principal: $380.94).
(a) What percentage of Payment #58 goes toward principal?
(b) Explain why making extra payments EARLY in a loan saves far more interest than making extra payments late in the loan.
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) $380.94 ÷ $386.66 = 0.9852 = 98.5%. Almost the entire payment now goes to principal, compared to only 74.1% in Payment #1. (b) Early in the loan, the balance is high ($20,000), so each month generates substantial interest ($100). An extra payment early reduces that high balance, which means every single future month charges less interest — and that savings compounds over the remaining 50+ payments. Late in the loan, the balance is already low ($762.89), interest is minimal ($5.72), and there are only a few payments left. There simply is not enough remaining interest to save. A $500 extra payment after Payment #1 saves interest across 58 future months; the same $500 after Payment #57 only affects 2-3 remaining months.

assessmentProblems.question:
Using the amortization table from Problem 7 (6.0% APR, monthly rate = 0.5%), suppose you make a one-time extra payment of $500 immediately after Payment #1, reducing your remaining balance from $19,713.34 to $19,213.34.

(a) What would the interest charge be on Payment #2 with the reduced balance?
(b) How much interest did the extra $500 save on that single month compared to the original $98.57?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) New interest on Payment #2 = $19,213.34 × 0.005 = $96.07. (b) Original interest was $98.57. Savings on one month = $98.57 − $96.07 = $2.50. This $2.50 monthly savings does not happen just once — the lower balance means every subsequent payment charges less interest too. The total interest savings from this single $500 extra payment compounds across the remaining 58 payments, saving approximately $80–$90 over the life of the loan. This is why financial advisors say the best time to make extra payments is as early as possible.

assessmentProblems.question:
A payday lender offers you $500 today and charges a flat fee of $75. The full amount ($575) is due in 2 weeks.

(a) What is the fee as a percentage of the amount borrowed?
(b) There are 26 two-week periods in a year. What is the approximate APR (annual percentage rate)?
assessmentProblems.answer: (a) $75 ÷ $500 = 0.15 = 15% for just two weeks. (b) APR = 15% × 26 = 390%. A $75 fee sounds small, but when you realize it is 15% for only 14 days, the annualized rate is 390%. For comparison, even a high-interest credit card charges about 25% APR. The payday loan costs more than 15 times as much. Payday lenders rely on the flat fee framing to make the cost seem reasonable.

assessmentProblems.question:
Identify ALL the red flags in this loan advertisement:

"EZ Cash — No credit check needed! Borrow $1,000 today! Only $89.99/week for 20 weeks. Don't worry about your credit score — everyone is approved! Call now, no paperwork required!"

For each red flag, explain why it is a warning sign. Also calculate the total cost of this loan.
assessmentProblems.answer: Total cost = $89.99 × 20 = $1,799.80 on a $1,000 loan. That is $799.80 in fees/interest — nearly 80% of the amount borrowed. Red flags: (1) 'No credit check' — legitimate lenders are required to verify a borrower's ability to repay; skipping this means they expect many borrowers to default and have built that into the price. (2) Weekly payment structure — quoting $89.99/week instead of total cost ($1,799.80) or APR deliberately obscures how expensive the loan is. (3) 'Everyone is approved' — no responsible lender approves every applicant regardless of ability to repay; this signals predatory intent. (4) 'No paperwork required' — legitimate lenders require income verification and a written agreement with clear terms; no paperwork means no consumer protections. (5) APR is never disclosed — federal Truth in Lending laws require APR disclosure; hiding it is a major red flag. Any one of these alone is concerning; all five together is a textbook predatory lender.

assessmentProblems.question:
Deshawn needs $800 for an emergency car repair. He has three options:

• Option A (Payday loan): Borrow $800 with a $120 fee, due in full in 2 weeks
• Option B (Credit card cash advance): $800 at 24.99% APR, plan to pay off in 3 months at $275.52/month
• Option C (Credit union personal loan): $800 at 10% APR for 12 months at $70.07/month

Calculate the total cost of each option. Which is the best choice, and why? Which should Deshawn avoid at all costs?
assessmentProblems.answer: Option A: Total = $800 + $120 = $920.00. Interest/fees = $120.00. APR equivalent = ($120 ÷ $800) × 26 = 390%. And if Deshawn cannot pay the full $920 in 2 weeks, he will likely roll over the loan, paying another $120 fee each cycle. The average payday borrower rolls over 8 times, which would mean $120 × 8 = $960 in fees alone — more than the original loan. Option B: Total = $275.52 × 3 = $826.56. Interest = $26.56. Option C: Total = $70.07 × 12 = $840.84. Interest = $40.84. Best choice: Option B if Deshawn can afford $275.52/month — lowest total cost at only $26.56 in interest. Option C if he needs lower monthly payments — only $14.28 more in total interest but spreads the payments to $70.07/month, which may be more manageable. Avoid at all costs: Option A. Even without rollovers, it costs the most ($120 vs $26.56 or $40.84). With rollovers, it becomes a debt trap that can cost more than the original loan amount.

answerKeys.ccr-5: Loan A total: $24,321.12; Loan B total: $26,866.80; Loan A saves $2,545.68
answerKeys.ccr-6: Loan C — total $18,985.92 vs Loan B $23,872.80; Loan C saves $1,886.88
answerKeys.ccr-7: 25.9% interest; decreases because balance decreases each month
answerKeys.ccr-8: 98.5% principal; early extra payments save more because balance is higher
answerKeys.ccr-11: 5 red flags; total cost $1,799.80 on $1,000 loan
answerKeys.ccr-12: Option B best ($826.56); Option A worst ($920+ with rollover risk)
